titleStmt.title: The treacherous brothers a tragedy, as it is acted by Their Majesty's servants at the Theatre-royal / written by George Powell.
titleStmt.author: Powell, George, 1658?-1714.

editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription A55546 of text R37128 in the English Short Title Catalog (Wing P3056). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 155 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 36 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

publicationStmt.pubPlace: Evanston,IL, Notre Dame, IN, St. Louis, MO

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal . The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The treacherous brothers a tragedy, as it is acted by Their Majesty's servants at the Theatre-royal / written by George Powell.

Bayly, Thomas, d. 1657? Herba parietis.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for James Blackwell ... and sold by Randal Taylor ...,

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.
The main incident is taken from Bayly's "Herba parietis, or, The wallflower."
"Epilogue. Writ by Mr. Mountfort, spoken by Mrs. Butler in mans apparel": p. [1] at end.

ep:epHeader.ep:defectRangePerGrade: The rate of 14.5 defects per 10,000 words puts this text in the C category of texts with between 10 and 35 defects per 10,000 words.
